semantic_title: Malignant Neoplasm Without Specification of Site
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 2. Chapter 2: Neoplasms > k. Malignant neoplasm without specification of site

content.full_text: Code C80.1, Malignant (primary) neoplasm, unspecified, equates to Cancer, unspecified. This code should only be used when no determination can be made as to the primary site of a malignancy. This code should rarely be used in the inpatient setting. (Evidence: pg no: 36, L93-L95)
content.summary: Guidelines for using C80.1 for malignant neoplasm when primary site cannot be determined (Evidence: pg no: 36, L93-L95)
key_concepts: Equates to Cancer, unspecified (Evidence: pg no: 36, L94)
Use only when no determination of primary site possible (Evidence: pg no: 36, L94-L95)
Should rarely be used in inpatient setting (Evidence: pg no: 36, L95)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use C80.1 only when no determination can be made as to primary site of malignancy (Evidence: pg no: 36, L94-L95)
detailed_rules.explanation: C80.1 is reserved for situations where there is clearly a malignancy but the primary site cannot be determined despite appropriate investigation (Evidence: pg no: 36, L94-L95)
common_applications: Cancer of unknown primary after extensive workup
Malignancy present but primary site cannot be identified

detailed_rules.rule_text: Should rarely be used in the inpatient setting (Evidence: pg no: 36, L95)
detailed_rules.explanation: In inpatient settings, there are usually more resources and time to determine the primary site, so this code should be used sparingly (Evidence: pg no: 36, L95)
common_applications: More appropriate for outpatient settings with limited diagnostic capability

workflow_steps: Step 2: Verify extensive attempts made to identify primary site

Step 4: Consider if inpatient setting allows for further investigation
Step 5: Use C80.1 only if truly no primary site can be identified
